title: Can you transplant a head to another body? - Max G. Levy

multiple-choice.question: What was Robert White's ultimate goal in performing the body transplant surgery on monkeys?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the mind-body divide

options.label: B
options.text: To develop a new technique for brain cooling

options.label: C
options.text: To one day perform this surgery on humans

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of paralysis on the brain

multiple-choice.question: What was the main challenge in reconnecting a severed spinal cord during the body transplant surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: The lack of oxygenated blood to the brain

options.label: B
options.text: The high energy demands of brain cells

options.label: C
options.text: The technical difficulty of reconnecting nerve endings

options.label: D
options.text: The risk of immune rejection

multiple-choice.question: What technique did Robert White develop to slow down the brain's metabolism and reduce its reliance on oxygen?

options.label: A
options.text: Brain cooling

options.label: B
options.text: Brain heating

options.label: C
options.text: Selective blood flow restriction

options.label: D
options.text: Oxygen therapy

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Robert White's experiment on the monkey body transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: The monkey died immediately after the surgery

options.label: B
options.text: The monkey survived but was paralyzed and distressed

options.label: C
options.text: The monkey recovered fully and was able to move normally

options.label: D
options.text: The monkey's brain was damaged beyond repair

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the philosophical questions raised by the idea of a body transplant?

options.label: A
options.text: Does part of the "self" reside outside of the mind?

options.label: B
options.text: Is it morally justifiable to perform such a surgery on humans?

options.label: C
options.text: Can a person's consciousness be transferred to a new body?

options.label: D
options.text: Is the mind-body divide a fixed or fluid concept?

title: How does an air conditioner actually work? - Anna Rothschild

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of heat pumps over traditional heaters?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more affordable to install.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more efficient and produce more heat with less energy.

options.label: C
options.text: They are more environmentally friendly due to the use of fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: They are more compact and require less space.

multiple-choice.question: How do heat pumps work in winter to heat a home?

options.label: A
options.text: They generate heat from electricity and transfer it to the home.

options.label: B
options.text: They pick up heat from outside and move it into the home using a refrigerant.

options.label: C
options.text: They use a compressor to heat up the air inside the home.

options.label: D
options.text: They rely on insulation to retain heat inside the home.

multiple-choice.question: What is a major drawback of using hydrofluorocarbons as refrigerants in heat pumps?

options.label: A
options.text: They are highly flammable.

options.label: B
options.text: They are toxic to humans.

options.label: C
options.text: They have a high global warming impact.

options.label: D
options.text: They are expensive to produce.

multiple-choice.question: Why do heat pumps become less efficient in extremely cold temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: The refrigerant becomes less effective at transferring heat.

options.label: B
options.text: The compressor has to work harder to heat the air.

options.label: C
options.text: The air outside is too cold to transfer heat to the refrigerant.

options.label: D
options.text: The heat pump's insulation becomes less effective.

multiple-choice.question: What is a creative way that some cities are harnessing heat sources for heat pumps?

options.label: A
options.text: Using solar panels to generate heat.

options.label: B
options.text: Harnessing heat from seas, sewage, and data centers.

options.label: C
options.text: Using geothermal energy to heat homes.

options.label: D
options.text: Implementing district heating systems.

title: Why don't "tough" and "dough" rhyme? - Arika Okrent

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Norman invasion of 1066 on the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: English became the language of authority and high society.

options.label: B
options.text: French became the language of authority and high society.

options.label: C
options.text: Latin became the dominant spoken language.

options.label: D
options.text: English was completely replaced by French.

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of the printing press on the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: It standardized English spelling.

options.label: B
options.text: It introduced new French words into the language.

options.label: C
options.text: It memorialized various spellings of words, leading to irregularities.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the language.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Great Vowel Shift in the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: A change in the pronunciation of consonants.

options.label: B
options.text: A change in the pronunciation of vowels between the 14th and 18th centuries.

options.label: C
options.text: A change in the spelling of words.

options.label: D
options.text: A change in the grammar of the language.

multiple-choice.question: Why do words like "dough", "tough", and "through" have similar spellings but distinct vowel sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the influence of Latin on the English language.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the Great Vowel Shift.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the haphazard application of French influence on English spelling.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the standardization of English spelling.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the complex history of the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: English is a simple and intuitive language to learn.

options.label: B
options.text: English is a difficult language for non-native speakers to learn.

options.label: C
options.text: English has a standardized spelling system.

options.label: D
options.text: English has a simple grammar system.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Anaerobic respiration

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to Brother David, what is the connection between happiness and gratefulness?

options.text: Happiness leads to gratefulness.

options.label: B
options.text: Gratefulness leads to happiness.

options.label: C
options.text: Happiness and gratefulness are unrelated.

options.label: D
options.text: Gratefulness is a prerequisite for happiness.

options.text: Appreciation for material possessions.

options.label: B
options.text: A feeling of happiness that arises when something valuable is given to us.

options.label: C
options.text: A sense of entitlement to what we have.

options.label: D
options.text: A feeling of sadness when we lose something.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing on the negative aspects of life.

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the present moment.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Run, Jump, and Play.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Respect and a willingness to share.

options.label: D
options.text: A sense of entitlement and complacency.

title: How do gas masks actually work? - George Zaidan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why a gas mask may not work effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: The filter is not designed to capture pollutants of a certain size.

options.label: B
options.text: The mask is not made of the right material.

options.label: C
options.text: The mask does not have a tight seal.

options.label: D
options.text: The mask is not used in the right environment.

multiple-choice.question: What type of pollutants can be captured by size-based filters?

options.label: A
options.text: Particulate matter larger than 2.5 microns in diameter.

options.label: B
options.text: Particulate matter smaller than 2.5 microns in diameter.

options.label: C
options.text: Ozone molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen sulfide gas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the special property of polypropylene branches in a filter that allows them to catch particles smaller than the gaps between them?

options.label: A
options.text: They are electrically charged.

options.label: B
options.text: They are made of a special material that attracts particles.

options.label: C
options.text: Van der Waals forces cause particles to stick to them.

options.label: D
options.text: They are designed to filter out objects larger than the sieve's holes.

multiple-choice.question: What type of filter is designed to capture pollutants that are too small for size-based filters, such as ozone molecules?

options.label: A
options.text: Activated carbon mask.

options.label: B
options.text: N95 mask.

options.label: C
options.text: N100 mask.

options.label: D
options.text: HEPA filter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of infusing a filter with a basic chemical or an acid?

options.label: A
options.text: To trap particulate matter.

options.label: B
options.text: To capture ozone molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: To react with and trap acidic or basic pollutants.

options.label: D
options.text: To improve the filter's efficiency.

title: Does math have a major flaw? - Jacqueline Doan and Alex Kazachek

multiple-choice.question: What is the Banach-Tarski paradox in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: A theorem that states a sphere cannot be divided into identical parts.

options.label: B
options.text: A result that shows a sphere can be divided into five identical parts and recombined into two identical spheres.

options.label: C
options.text: A proof that demonstrates the impossibility of dividing a sphere into identical parts.

options.label: D
options.text: A statement that claims a sphere can only be divided into two identical parts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the foundation of every mathematical system?

options.label: A
options.text: Theorems

options.label: B
options.text: Axioms

options.label: C
options.text: Proofs

options.label: D
options.text: Equations

multiple-choice.question: What is the Axiom of Choice in mathematics?

options.label: A
options.text: An axiom that states a set can only have a finite number of elements.

options.label: B
options.text: An axiom that allows for the selection of elements from sets, even if they are infinite and indistinguishable.

options.label: C
options.text: An axiom that implies a line and a point off the line can have only one parallel line.

options.label: D
options.text: An axiom that states a sphere can be divided into identical parts.

multiple-choice.question: Why do mathematicians not reject the Axiom of Choice despite its counterintuitive results?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is not load-bearing for important results in mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it only leads to impractical results.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is necessary for certain fields like measure theory and functional analysis.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is the only axiom that allows for the selection of elements from sets.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the coexistence of mathematics with and without the Axiom of Choice?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that mathematics is limited to only one set of axioms.

options.label: B
options.text: It demonstrates that mathematics is a fixed and unchanging field.

options.label: C
options.text: It highlights the freedom mathematics gives us to choose the axioms that suit our purposes.

options.label: D
options.text: It proves that the Axiom of Choice is unnecessary for mathematics.

options.label: D
options.text: Marine Conservation Institute

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the goal of establishing marine protected areas?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect biodiversity

options.label: B
options.text: To provide stability and resilience

options.label: C
options.text: To promote sustainable fishing practices

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's wish for the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To reduce their carbon footprint

options.label: B
options.text: To use public transportation

options.label: C
options.text: To support a global network of marine protected areas

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce their use of plastic bags

title: Picture a perfect society. What does it look like? - Joseph Lacey

multiple-choice.question: What is the main purpose of John Rawls' thought experiment, known as "the original position"?

options.label: A
options.text: To design a society with maximum wealth and power

options.label: B
options.text: To identify principles that support a realistic utopia

options.label: C
options.text: To promote free market philosophies

options.label: D
options.text: To advocate for Marxism

multiple-choice.question: What is the "veil of ignorance" in John Rawls' thought experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: A state of complete knowledge about oneself and others

options.label: B
options.text: A state of partial knowledge about oneself and others

options.label: C
options.text: A state of ignorance about certain information about oneself and others

options.label: D
options.text: A state of complete ignorance about everything

multiple-choice.question: According to John Rawls, what is the "difference principle"?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are only acceptable when they benefit the most advantaged citizens

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are only acceptable when they benefit the least advantaged citizens

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are always unacceptable

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that wealth inequalities are irrelevant to a just society

multiple-choice.question: What is "property owning democracy," according to John Rawls?

options.label: A
options.text: A system where only the wealthy own property

options.label: B
options.text: A system where the government owns all property

options.label: C
options.text: A system where everyone has equal access to education and healthcare, and the government regulates property and wealth

options.label: D
options.text: A system where property is distributed randomly

multiple-choice.question: Who has critiqued John Rawls' work, arguing that the difference principle unfairly tethers society's progress to the status of the worst-off?

options.label: A
options.text: Martha Nussbaum

options.label: B
options.text: Ronald Dworkin

options.label: C
options.text: John Rawls himself

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

title: The Nazis recruited to win the Cold War - Brian Crim

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of Operation Paperclip?

options.label: A
options.text: To bring German scientists to the US to stand trial for war crimes

options.label: B
options.text: To recruit German scientists to work for the US government before the Soviets could

options.label: C
options.text: To grant citizenship to German families who were displaced by the war

options.label: D
options.text: To dismantle German factories and steal patents

multiple-choice.question: Why was Wernher von Braun's past as a Nazi largely hidden from the public?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was ashamed of his involvement with the Nazi party

options.label: B
options.text: Because the US government wanted to avoid controversy and criticism

options.label: C
options.text: Because von Braun's work on the Saturn V rocket was not significant

options.label: D
options.text: Because the US government did not know about his past

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the rocket that Wernher von Braun's team developed to bring Americans to the moon?

options.label: A
options.text: Saturn I

options.label: B
options.text: Saturn V

options.label: C
options.text: Apollo 11

options.label: D
options.text: Sputnik

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the criticisms of Operation Paperclip?

options.label: A
options.text: That it was too expensive to relocate German families

options.label: B
options.text: That it was unfair to grant citizenship to German scientists while millions of displaced persons had no chance of coming to America

options.label: C
options.text: That it was a failure because it did not produce any significant scientific contributions

options.label: D
options.text: That it was a secret operation that was not revealed to the press

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the US government's decision to recruit German scientists through Operation Paperclip?

options.label: A
options.text: The US fell behind the Soviets in the Space Race

options.label: B
options.text: The US developed the atomic bomb

options.label: C
options.text: The US made significant advancements in rocketry and other scientific fields

options.label: D
options.text: The US lost the Cold War

title: How to prevent political corruption - Stephanie Honchell Smith

multiple-choice.question: What is corruption often defined as?

options.label: A
options.text: A misuse of a position of power for the greater good.

options.label: B
options.text: A misuse of a position of power for personal gain.

options.label: C
options.text: A misuse of a position of power for financial gain only.

options.label: D
options.text: A misuse of a position of power for the benefit of others.

multiple-choice.question: What was Mcebisi Jonas offered by the Gupta family in exchange for advancing their business interests?

options.label: A
options.text: A promotion and $10 million.

options.label: B
options.text: A promotion and $45 million.

options.label: C
options.text: A promotion and a luxury car.

options.label: D
options.text: A promotion and a high-end watch.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that corruption can snowball?

options.label: A
options.text: If anti-corruption laws are enforced too strictly.

options.label: B
options.text: If anti-corruption laws aren’t enforced, or if loopholes are continuously exploited.

options.label: C
options.text: If corruption is limited to the political sphere.

options.label: D
options.text: If corruption is only driven by greed.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Gupta family's corruption schemes in South Africa?

options.label: A
options.text: The country's economy was boosted.

options.label: B
options.text: The country's economy was devastated.

options.label: C
options.text: The country's economy was unaffected.

options.label: D
options.text: The country's economy was slightly impacted.

multiple-choice.question: How can citizens help prevent corruption?

options.label: A
options.text: By voting out those who engage in corruption and questioning officials who push back against transparency measures.

options.label: B
options.text: By ignoring corruption and hoping it goes away.

options.label: C
options.text: By participating in corrupt activities themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: By only relying on laws to set a high price for corrupt behavior.
